comments:
We have the need to have a fragment whose host is org.eclipse.swt.  With this fragment built and in the eclipse\plugins directory I could no longer "Run as SWT..." but with it loaded in my workspace I didn't have any issues.  The exception thrown with it built and in the plugin directory is:

java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: no swt-win32-3139 in java.library.path
	at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadLibrary(Unknown Source)
	at java.lang.Runtime.loadLibrary0(Unknown Source)
	at java.lang.System.loadLibrary(Unknown Source)
	at org.eclipse.swt.internal.Library.loadLibrary(Library.java:123)
	at org.eclipse.swt.internal.win32.OS.<clinit>(OS.java:18)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.<clinit>(Display.java:125)
	at CComboTesting.run(CComboTesting.java:16)
	at CComboTesting.main(CComboTesting.java:43)

The problem is that when the JVM is being invoked my plugin is being loaded as the java.library.path fragment:

 "C:\Program Files\Java\j2re1.4.2_07\bin\javaw.exe" "-Djava.library.path=c:/Program Files/eclipse/plugins/com.bedrock.swt_1.0.0.jar/os/win32/x86"...

I tracked this down to org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.launcher.SWTLaunchConfiguration.findFragment():

BundleDescription[] fragments = desc.getFragments();
if (fragments.length > 0) {
     return fragments[0];
}

The call to desc.getFragments() is returning the correct fragments but the code above just takes the first and since my plugin ID comes before org.eclipse.swt alphabetically it was chosen as the fragment that contains the system libraries.

The workaround I employed was to rename my fragment so that it came after org.eclipse.swt.

same root cause.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 113240 ***
